I know. eh. Many people believe Canada is "nothing but a frozen wasteland" (direct quote) however though there remains a few places that are extremely cold during winter, within a short period of time that area has diminished considerably. https://blog.metoffice.gov.uk/2024/05/02/the-atlantic-meridional-overturning-circulation-in-a-changing-climate/#:~:text=AMOC%20collapse&text=Although%20this%20is%20unlikely%20to,on%20ecosystems%20and%20human%20activities.

card.title: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation in a changing climate
card.description: For 20 years, an array of instruments strung across the North Atlantic has been monitoring the strength of one of the largest and most important systems of ocean currents in the world.   …
card.provider_name: Official blog of the Met Office news team

descendants.content:
@davidnjoku @neverbeaten about 20 years ago I was studying environmental science. We studied the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation system and we never questioned whether it could happen if the arctic continued melting, it was only a question of when AMOC would stop. Eventually the arctic either dumps too much cold water all at once or the cold water flows slow or even warm up to the point where they are no longer considered cold. Doesn't much matter what exactly causes it to stop, just that it eventually will stop due to physics. If I recall correctly, we were under the impression AMOC would encounter slowing problems at the 2.0°c mark and if by 2050 we were at 2.5°c the odds of AMOC collapse were better than the odds of winning at roulette.

Of course this is all information I pulled out of an education I recieved twenty years ago. So those numbers are probably wildly wrong today. Or even wrong back then.

descendants.content:
@davidnjoku @PlumpCat
I'm not a climate scientist, but I've been paying close attention to what they're saying for about the past 20 years or so.

The trend is there's always a range of predictions/forecasting from relatively dire to not so bad. The way the predictions have played out over time is usually a bit beyond or way beyond the dire. They're all afraid of losing funding, so they always tweak their predictions to favor the kindest possible outcomes.

account.note: Progressive democratic socialist. Bass player in original bands ranging from folk to trip-hop. Live sound engineer. Dabbling in recording, mixing, and mastering. I love nerding out about all sorts of technical and scientific things. Advocate and ally.

descendants.content:
@davidnjoku @PlumpCat
So lately I've been looking at the most extreme predictions and presuming they softened those up a bit. Plus there are always new feedback systems we're discovering that accelerate predicted effects.

I would in no way be surprised if the AMOC nearly stops within 15 years.

descendants.content:
@davidnjoku in north western canada my childhood in the winter was one surrounded by colored ice bricks we would make out of Tupperware and food coloring. About 4 or 5 years ago I managed to recreate some of that with my nieces and nephews but it was an incredible amount of work due to the weather barely cooperating. I have not tried this since and can't help but wonder if I'll never get to build colorful ice block forts again.

The probelm isn't temperatures staying below zero. It is temperatures in the sun staying below zero all day. If you can't get a good freeze even while the sun is shining, you cannot do this. The bolder the color of the ice block, the cooler it needs to be as they start absorbing a lot of infrared.

I remember my school playgrounds having hundreds upon hundreds of colorful frozen ice blocks. Sunday school would have us slaving away to build a little colored ice brick wall that would sometimes grow too large and collapse dangerously. I remember one year the town actually had little colored inukshuk at every intersection that the youth group made every week.

I seriously haven't seen a colored ice brick wall in decades. Ice block forts seem to be a thing of the past as well and I can't even remember the last time I saw a colorful inuksuk.

It is unfortunate but not at all unpredicted.

descendants.content:
@davidnjoku

My experience, growing up in Britain...

I was in South Wales. Only one or two times did I ever see snow at Christmas.

Many years the snow, if we had any, was gone as soon as it fell.

That was my experience between the 70s and 2005 anyway.

I remember 1973 as a particularly hot summer - so hot people's lawns were catching fire.
